comments.body: You can use System.currentTimeMillis() to get the current time in milliseconds since epoch.
@devgianlu Better to use System.nanoTime(), for more precision, when calculating elapsed time.

And for the record: you are supposed to do serious research prior posting questions. An experience coder could know how to first use a search engine ... to find answer in way less time than required to put a question here.

One executes a merthod, not a class., That being said, the simple solution is System.nanoTime(). For the correct solution, look up Java Microbenchmark. One of teh first things that pop up is stackoverflow.com/questions/504103/…

answers.title: java - Show, how much time passed by executing a class?
answers.body:
You can get the current time at the beginning and at the end of the code, and subtract them:

long s = System.nanoTime();

//Your code;

long elapsed = System.nanoTime() - s;

Your time elapsed will be in nanoseconds, but it's an easy conversion.

answers.title: JLabel custom event setText
answers.body: As @Oleksandr indicated in his comment. In a java Swing application, i.e. an application that uses classes from javax.swing package, like JLabel, a special thread is launched. This thread is known by many names, including Event Dispatch Thread or EDT. As @Oleksandr indicated, your code that calls method setText() in class JLabel must be executed on this thread. The class @Oleksandr mentioned - javax.swing.SwingUtilities - also contains [static] method isDispatchThread() which returns true if called from the EDT. If not called from the EDT, then you can call method invokeLater(), also in class SwingUtilities which ensures that it will execute on the EDT.

answers.title: "Failed to allocate memory" and "Expiring record" error after Kafka broker is down for 5+ mins and then rejoins the cluster
answers.body:
Finally figured out how to fix this. Posting it here in case it's useful to somebody else.

Our producer.send call had a callback defined that, in the event of an error, would attempt to re-send the message, using the same producer, to another topic. This mechanism had been built so that, if the send call resulted in an error, we'd at least have the message stored in an error topic, where we could inspect the data and figure out what was going on.

This mechanism usually worked well, but whenever we lost a broker temporarily (had to take it down for maintenance/upgrades/etc), all of our applications would get stuck and eventually killed by the ELB.

From the official Javadoc for KafkaProducer.send(), I found this:

Note that callbacks will generally execute in the I/O thread of the producer and so should be reasonably fast or they will delay the sending of messages from other threads. If you want to execute blocking or computationally expensive callbacks it is recommended to use your own Executor in the callback body to parallelize processing.

https://kafka.apache.org/11/javadoc/index.html?org/apache/kafka/clients/producer/KafkaProducer.html

The producer.send inside the callback qualifies as an expensive call, IMHO. After doing some further debugging and profiling, it turns out all the XNIO threads were getting stuck while the callback producer.send() call was waiting on stale metadata, I guess, from when the broker rejoined the cluster. This eventually caused the application to stop responding.

The fix in our case was to simply enqueue the error message in a ConcurrentLinkedDeque, and have those messages be handled by a separate thread, whose only job was to take messages from the deque and try to re-send them.

After deploying this change to all our environments, the application has behaved perfectly throughout multiple broker restarts and outages.

title: "Failed to allocate memory" and "Expiring record" error after Kafka broker is down for 5+ mins and then rejoins the cluster
body:
We're doing some testing on Kafka 1.1 brokers in AWS EC2. Specifically, we're cleanly shutting brokers down for 5 mins or more, and then restarting them, while producing and consuming from the cluster all the time. In theory, this should be relatively seamless to both producers and consumers.

However, we're getting these errors on the producer application when testing a broker being down for over 5 mins:

 ERROR - 2019-02-27 04:34:24.946 - message size [2494] 
       -Expiring 7 record(s) for topic2-0: 30033 ms has passed since last append

And then the first of many errors similar to this. 

 ERROR - 2019-02-27 04:35:13.098; Topic [topic2], message size [2494] 
       -Failed to allocate memory within the configured max blocking time 60000 ms.

At that point, the long-running producers become non-responsive, and every producer request fails with that same Failed to allocate memory. I tried to search online for similar issues, but all I could find is an old Kafka JIRA ticket that was resolved in 0.10.1.1, so it shouldn't apply for the newer 1.1 version we're using.

https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/KAFKA-3651

We have attempted a lot of different scenarios, including changing the producer configuration back to Kafka defaults, to see if anything would help, but we always run into that problem whenever a broker comes back into the cluster after being down for 5 mins or more.
